NarNarrative: This species is a hardy grass that can be found throughout North America, Europe and Asia. It has also been introduced to Australia and New Zealand. It is common in upland areas on poor soils, but tolerates a broad range of environmental conditions. Its name, Viviparous Fescue, refers to the fact that the adult plant produces seedlings rather than seeds.

A hardy grass species that is found throughout the northern hemisphere. It grows up to 25cm high. It grows on a variety of different soil types, and can withstand drought conditions and winter temperatures down to about 35 degrees below zero. It can also withstand heavy grazing and is a nutritious fodder species for livestock, although it generally produces low yields.

This is a very common and widespread species which occurs throughout Europe, Asia and North America. It grows on moist, nutrient rich soils. It is very nutritious and withstands heavy grazing, as well as being very palatable to livestock. This makes it an important agricultural species.

Perennial Rye-Grass is a temperate zone grass species that prefers moist, nutrient rich soils. It is a very important fodder crop for livestock due to its high nitrogen content, rapid growth rate and ability to withstand heavy grazing. For this reason it has been grown all over the world. It is also used to make hay and silage. Many different varieties have been bred.

This species grows on moist, nutrient rich soils in temperate areas with moderate climates throughout Europe and North America. It can be found in damp grassland areas, woodland and marshes. It flowers during June and July. It is a widespread and abundant species.

This species is a small grass that is found mainly in coastal areas. It is native to Europe, north Africa and temperate Asia, and has been introduced to Western Australia, where it is a significant weed species. It is extremely drought and heat tolerant and normally grows in dry, sandy soils.

LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear (NE England), South Shields, at the links

NarNarrative: This is a small fern which grows throughout Eurasia and North America. It produces dense upright tufts of leaves and prefers rocky environments such as mountain slopes and cliffs. It is normally found on slate or calcareous rocks, particularly limestone. The name 'Woodsia' comes from the botanist Joseph Woods (1776-1864) who first described the species.

This is a small plant that grows in damp, shaded environments. It is commonly found growing in rock crevices and on the forest floor in deep shade. It has a superficial resemblance to tufts of moss. The tiny leaves are very thin and are semi-transparent, hence the name 'filmy-fern'. It is found growing in suitable conditions all over the British Isles.

SciName: Rubus plicatus var. bertramii : Rosaceae : Rosales : :
Rubus plicatus wh. and n. : Rosaceae : Rosales : :

NarNarrative: This species is widespread on acid soils in moist, woodland environments throughout Europe, Asia and temperate North America. It prefers slightly acid soils, and will also grow on rocky surfaces in areas which receive lots of rainfall. It belongs to a distinctive group of species that produce bright red reproductive structures. They are all very similar, and correct identification depends on close examination.

This species grows in tufts on the branches of trees. It is found in forested areas throughout Europe, North America and Asia. It was traditionally ground into a powder and used as an antiseptic in parts of Siberia. Subsequent tests on the lichen have revealed that it contains large quantities of Usnic Acid, which has strong antibiotic properties.

This seaweed is known as Dabberlocks in Scotland and Wing Kelp or Bladder Locks in England. The name Wing Kelp comes from the two rows of leafy reproductive structures, called sporophylls, growing from the stipe (stem) near the holdfast. This seaweed usually grows on rocks that are exposed to sea action and in rock pools at low water. It is the only kelp-like seaweed in Britain and Ireland that has a distinct midrib and has leaflets at the base of the frond. This specimen comes from the foot of the castle at Tynemouth, Tyne and Wear.
SciName: Laminariales & Alariaceae & Alaria esculenta (L.) Grev. : : : Phaeophyceae :
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear, Tynemouth (Castle Foot)
MulDescription: <SUMMARY-DESCRIPT>: The midrib running through the frond of this seaweed is a characteristic used to identify it as a Wing Kelp. There is a short stipe (stem) between the frond and the claw-like holdfast at the bottom., The leafy sporophylls growing from the stipe are another characteristic used to identify this specimen as a Wing Kelp. The sporophylls contain the reproductive organs. The holdfast is used to hold the seaweed onto a rock.

NarNarrative: This beautiful seaweed goes by the name of Plocamium cartilagineum because it has no common name. It grows in the intertidal zone nearest the sea as well as in shallow water just below the lowest tide. This specimen comes from Spittal, Northumberland and is from the W.C. Trevelyan collection.
SciName: Rhodophyta & Florideophyceae & Gigartinales & Plocamiaceae & Plocamium cartilagineum (L.) Dixon : : : : Rhodophyta
MulDescription: <SUMMARY-DESCRIPT>: The colour and shape of Plocamium cartilagineum makes it a popular choice with collectors. It is easily pressed to display in an attractive way. The most recent name appears on the label attached to the sheet and is crossed out and replaced with newer names over time., It is common practise to keep the original name of a plant on the herbarium sheet. In this case, the old name is Plocamium coccineum. Names sometimes change as more research is done., Plocamium cartilagineum is a good example of a seaweed whose name has changed over time. Historically, it has been confused with several other seaweeds. Some scientists believe that it is still not classified in the right family so there may be more changes to come.

NarNarrative: Sea lettuce gets this name because its fronds look like lettuce. It is common in the part of the intertidal zone (the area between the lowest and highest tides) that is nearest to the sea. Sea lettuce is usually attached to rocks but can grow into large mats on top of the water in very sheltered areas. This specimen comes from the Berwick upon Tweed area of Northumberland and was once part of the Nathaniel J. Winch collection.
SciName: Chlorophyta & Chlorophyceae & Ulvales & Ulvaceae & Ulva lactuca L. : : : : Chlorophyta
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland, Berwick upon Tweed (nr.)

NarNarrative: All but the specimen in the top left corner are examples of Chondrus crispus. The other related seaweed is called Gigartina stellata. Both are collected as Carrageen or Irish Moss. Carrageenan is extracted from these algae and used in foods such as ice cream to prevent ice crystals from forming. It is also useful for making soups and jellies and is even found in toothpaste. Irish Moss grows in the intertidal zone nearest the sea as well as in shallow water just below the lowest tide. These specimens are from the N.J. Winch collection.
SciName: Rhodophyta & Florideophyceae & Gigartinales & Gigartinaceae & Chondrus crispus Stackh. : : : : Rhodophyta
MulDescription: <SUMMARY-DESCRIPT>: This herbarium sheet holds five specimens of Chondrus crispus and one (top left) of Gigartina stellata. The Gigartina stellata looks very similar to the Chondrus crispus but the flattened part (blade) tends to roll inwards to form a channel., Collectors usually try to press the whole plant so that all parts are present. In this case, the stipes (stems) radiate from the holdfast and branch into fronds or blades., This specimen of Chondrus crispus is missing its holdfast. You may find lots of these washed up on the shoreline after a storm.

NarNarrative: Palmaria palmata, also known as "Dulse", gets its scientific name from its similarity to the shape of a human hand. It is common in the intertidal zone, particularly near low water. Sun dried dulse is eaten as is or ground into flakes or powder for use in soups, chowders and other foods. Dulse is low in sodium but high in some vitamins, iron and potassium. This specimen comes from St. Mary's Island, Tyne and Wear & England & UK.
SciName: Rhodophyta & Florideophyceae & Palmariales & Palmariaceae & Palmaria palmata (L.) O. Kuntze : : : : Rhodophyta
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear, St. Mary's Island

NarNarrative: Purple laver is an ingredient in the laver bread that is traditionally prepared for the feast day of the Welsh patron saint, St. David. Laver is also boiled and then eaten as a jelly, or sometimes eaten cold with vinegar. Laver is found in the intertidal zone, often in the areas that are furthest from the sea. This specimen comes from Spittal in Northumberland & England & UK.
SciName: Rhodophyta & Bangiophyceae & Bangiales & Bangiaceae & Porphyra umbilicalis (L.) J. Ag. : : : : Rhodophyta

NarNarrative: This seaweed gets the name 'green sea fingers', or 'dead man's fingers', from its shape. It is not native to Britain and probably arrived here attached to shellfish, such as oysters, on the hulls of ships travelling from the Pacific Ocean. Only one cell forms the body of this seaweed. This specimen comes from Ross Sands in Northumberland .
SciName: Chlorophyta & Chlorophyceae & Codiales & Codiaceae & Codium fragile (Sur.) Hariot subsp. atlanticum (Cotton) Silva : : : : Chlorophyta

NarNarrative: Knotted Wrack gets its name from the shape formed by the single air bladders in each of the long, flattened fronds. This seaweed drapes down over intertidal rocks and has many fronds growing from its base, known as a 'holdfast'. These fronds are replaced when the old ones break off. Knotted Wrack grows slowly and is reported to live for several decades. This specimen comes from St. Mary's Island, Tyne and Wear .
SciName: Fucales & Fucaceae & Ascophyllum nodosum (L.) Le Jol. : : : Phaeophyceae :
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear, St. Mary's Island
MulDescription: <SUMMARY-DESCRIPT>: The reddish-brown tufts of algae growing on this specimen are Polysiphonia lanosa, a species that is often associated with Knotted Wrack. It lives on the Knotted Wrack without harming it so it is considered to be an epiphyte., The single bladders of Knotted Wrack differentiate this seaweed from Bladder Wrack which has paired bladders. The bladders help the plant float closer to the surface when it is under water. Like all seaweeds, it needs light in order to manufacture its food.

NarNarrative: This seaweed is tubular and takes the shape of intestines. It is aptly called Enteromorpha (meaning 'form') intestinalis (meaning 'of the intestines'), or Green Sea Intestines. This green alga grows in both marine and freshwater environments as it is able to adapt to extremes in salt levels. It is one of the most common seaweeds in Britain.

Bladder Wrack gets its name from the air bladders that form either side of the midrib in each frond. The paired bladders differentiate this seaweed from Knotted Wrack which has single bladders. Bladder wrack usually lives in the middle part of the intertidal zone. This specimen comes from Beadnell, Northumberland .
MulDescription: <SUMMARY-DESCRIPT>: The air bladders located on either side of the midrib are characteristic of this Bladder Wrack specimen. The fronds are neither spiralled nor serrated (like a steak knife). The swollen areas at the ends of the fronds contain the reproductive organs., The air bladders in Bladder Wrack usually come in pairs. Air bladders help the seaweed to float towards the surface when the tide is in. The seaweed receives more light which it needs in order to manufacture its food., The holdfast on Bladder Wrack is a small disc. It anchors the seaweed to a rock to keep it from drifting away in the water.

NarNarrative: The Common Dog Violet is widespread throughout Britain and Europe. It grows in deciduous woodland as well as a variety of grassland environments, on both acid and calcareous soils. The flowers vary in colour from dark bluish-purple to white. The violet has a specialised seedpod that bursts open when ripe, spraying seeds out up to a metre from the parent plant. In this way the violet can disperse it's seeds over relatively long distances.
SciName: Viola riviniana reichenb. : Violaceae : Malpighiales : : Spermatophyta

NarNarrative: The Maiden Pink lives in a variety of different habitats throughout Europe and temperate Asia. It is a perennial herb with bright pink flowers that forms dense mats in dry, sunny places. It normally prefers light, well drained, alkaline soils and is often found along roads and on patches of waste ground.

ColPhysicalDescription: Plant 'Plantae & Magnoliaphyta & Magnoliopsida & Myrtales & Thymelaeaceae & Daphne : : : :'
NarNarrative: Daphne sericea forms low growing, dense bushes that produce fragrant pink flowers. This species is native to the southern Mediterranean region but has become naturalised in many areas, including parts of North America. It is often grown as an ornamental plant due to its flowers and strong fragrance.
SciName: Plantae & Magnoliaphyta & Magnoliopsida & Myrtales & Thymelaeaceae & Daphne : : : :

NarNarrative: This low growing plant is found in coastal areas across Europe and Asia. It has also become naturalised in North America. It is adapted to sandy, salty environments and is particularly common on saltmarshes. It has thick and fleshy leaves that store water, and produces lots of small pink flowers during the summer.
LocalSum: Europe, France, Var, Sea Shore Near Almanarre

NarNarrative: This low growing plant is found in coastal areas across Europe and Asia. It has also become naturalised in North America. It is adapted to sandy, salty environments and is particularly common on saltmarshes. It has thick and fleshy leaves that store water, and produces lots of small pink flowers during the summer.
LocalSum: Europe, France, Var, Hyeres, Mt Des Oiseaux, Woods

NarNarrative: This short and rather delicate plant produces white flowers and small leaves that have a swelling or 'knot' at the base, hence its common name. It grows on damp sandy or peaty soils, including sand dunes in coastal areas.

LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Gilsland (nr.), Hardrew

NarNarrative: This is a tall, upright flowering plant is a member of the Borage family that grows on well drained sandy or calcareous soils in sunny areas. It produces dense stalks of bright blue flowers. It is naturally occurring on dry grassland, often near the coast. However, it is an opportunistic species and is also found on bare slopes or recently disturbed ground such as building sites.

This small plant is found in damp, marshy places. It often grows on very nutrient poor soils, such as bogs in upland areas. It supplements its supply of nutrients by catching insects. The rosette of small yellowish leaves at the base of the plant are covered with sticky glands that trap and digest small beetles and flies. It produces a single purple flower that grows on a long stem at the centre of the rosette of leaves.

This species occurs throughout Europe and Asia. It forms dense prickly clumps of sharply pointed leaves that grow up to about a metre high. It produces small tufts of brown flowers that grow sideways out from the stem. The seeds germinate in damp conditions on a wide variety of soils, frequently alongside ponds and rivers. However, the plant does not require wet soil once it is established.
LocalSum: UK, England, Devon, Bideford, Braunton Burrows

NarNarrative: This is a very hardy species that is found in alpine meadows throughout the northern temperate and arctic regions. It grows on wet sites in shallow soils as well as sand and gravel, and will tolerate temporary flooding. It occurs up to the snowline in the Rocky Mountains of North America, and can withstand ice and severe frosts. It is not normally a dominant species, and is most often found growing in association with other rushes, sedges and herbaceous species.
LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Tayside (Scotland), Forfar, Clova, Glen Dole

NarNarrative: This species is a generalist, and is common throughout the northern hemisphere. It grows in a wide variety of conditions, including coastal marshes and estuaries, beaches, moorland, around freshwater lakes and ponds and arctic tundra. It has been recorded from sea level up to about 2000 ft. It often forms dense mats in wet or flooded areas.
LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Tayside (Scotland), Sands of Barrie

NarNarrative: A common and widespread sedge that is found in wet environments such as upland moorland, marshes and coastal areas. It is easily recognised by its fruit, which are shiny and dark brown, and are said to resemble several fleas attached to the stem.
LocalSum: UK, England, Cumbria, The Gelt (near), Gelt House Farm

NarNarrative: This tall reedy plant is found in marshy places all over the world. It is a rapid coloniser of exposed wet soil and shallow water, and will tolerate a broad range of environmental conditions. Common habitats include wet meadows, marshes, fens, pond and lake margins and coastal estuaries. It is an important source of food and habitat for many animals. It has also been used by humans to produce a wide range of materials including baskets, roofing material and paper.
SciName: Plantae & Magnoliaphyta & Lilopsida & Typhales & Typhaceae & Typha : : : :
LocalSum: UK, England, North Yorkshire (NE England), Scarbrough Mere
UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Crag Lough

NarNarrative: This species is native to Europe and Asia. It grows on damp, acid soils, and can normally be found in swampy woodland and moorland areas. The leaves are very stiff and sharply pointed at the tip, and grow upright to a height of about a metre. It produces small clusters of brown flowers in the summer months.
SciName: Juncus acutiflorus ehrh. ex hoffm. : Juncaceae : Poales : :

LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Highland (Scotland), Clashnessie, Loch An Easain (nr.)

NarNarrative: This species is common in the northern temperate zone in Europe, Asia and North America. It is found throughout the British Isles. It grows in wet environments with peaty soils, such as bogs and moorland areas. It is easily identified by its fruit, which are arranged in star-like brown clusters, giving the plant its common name.
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Muckle Moss
UK, England, Tyne and Wear (NE England), Clara Vale

NarNarrative: This species is found in the temperate and arctic regions of North America, Europe and Asia. It is restricted to wet, mossy peatland in mountainous areas. It grows up to 30 cm high, and spreads via an extensive network of long, creeping shoots.

This sedge species is native to marshes, fens and seasonally inundated grassland. Although it is relatively uncommon in Britain it can be very abundant in the locations where it grows. It can be found in temperate areas throughout Europe and Asia, on a variety of different soils.

This grass-like plant is native to temperate regions of Europe and Asia and has been introduced to North America. It has long, upright leaves and stems and grows in small clusters in wet places. It is semi-aquatic, and will grow in several centimetres of water. It is very similar to several other species, and can only be identified by the structure of its tiny flowers, which have just three petals.

This lichen is found in damp, forested areas throughout Europe, temperate Asia and North America. It is very sensitive to chemical pollution, and in many areas it is used as an indicator of unpolluted environments. This species was used in traditional medicine throughout the world to treat lung diseases. In parts of Siberia, the lichen was also added as a bitter flavouring to beer during the brewing process.

This species is found throughout the world's temperate regions, in Europe, Asia and North America. It forms large, leafy patches, and can be found in moist conditions in a wide variety of habitats, although it prefers to grow on acidic soils or granite rocks. It's common name, 'Pixie Cup' refers to the lichen's reproductive structures, known as podetia, which are just a few centimetres high and shaped like tiny goblets.
